description: High-level legal research framework for Canadian law. Covers how to find statutes, regulations, cases, and secondary sources; how to read a case; and how to validate authority using public tools.

topics.title: Hierarchy of Legal Sources in Canada
topics.coreDefinition: Canadian legal authority generally flows from constitutional law, statutes (and regulations), and case law. Secondary sources interpret but do not create binding law.
frameworkSteps: Identify the legal issue and relevant jurisdiction (federal vs province/territory).
Check for governing statute(s) and regulations first.
Review leading cases interpreting that statute.
Consult secondary sources for context and interpretation.
quickExamples: Employment standards: Start with the provincial Employment Standards Act, then look at tribunal or court interpretations.
Criminal law: Refer to the Criminal Code (federal), then leading Supreme Court cases.
commonMistakes: Relying solely on blog posts without checking statutes.
Ignoring jurisdiction (Ontario vs Alberta rules may differ).
Confusing persuasive authority with binding authority.

intentSignals: where can i read the law

topics.title: Finding Statutes and Regulations
topics.coreDefinition: Statutes are enacted by legislatures (Parliament or provincial assemblies). Regulations are subordinate legislation made under statutory authority.
frameworkSteps: Identify jurisdiction (federal or province/territory).
Search official government websites for consolidated statutes.
Check regulations linked to the statute.
Confirm currency (in force date and amendments).
quickExamples: Ontario: e-Laws website for statutes and regulations.
commonMistakes: Not checking if the section has been amended.

topics.title: Case Law Research
topics.coreDefinition: Case law consists of judicial decisions interpreting statutes or developing common law principles.
frameworkSteps: Search CanLII or official court websites.
Identify leading or frequently cited cases.
Note the court level (Supreme Court decisions bind lower courts).
Check if the case has been followed, distinguished, or overturned.
quickExamples: Use keyword search plus jurisdiction filter on CanLII.
Review headnotes for quick overview but read key reasoning sections.
commonMistakes: Not verifying whether a case is still good law.

topics.title: How to Read a Case
topics.coreDefinition: Judicial decisions contain procedural history, facts, issues, reasoning, and a holding (ratio decidendi).
frameworkSteps: Identify material facts.
Determine the legal issue(s).
Extract the court’s reasoning.
Isolate the binding principle (ratio).
Distinguish obiter dicta from binding reasoning.
quickExamples: Ratio: The principle necessary for the decision.
Obiter: Comments not essential to the decision.

intentSignals: how do i read a case

topics.title: Noting Up and Validating Authority
topics.coreDefinition: Noting up is the process of checking how a case or statute has been treated by subsequent decisions.
frameworkSteps: Use citation tools (e.g., CanLII’s cited-by feature).
Check if the decision was overturned or distinguished.
Confirm the section of statute is still in force.
quickExamples: Look for 'overruled' or 'reversed' in citing cases.

topics.title: Using Secondary Sources
topics.coreDefinition: Secondary sources include textbooks, law review articles, legal encyclopedias, and practice guides. They interpret but do not bind.
frameworkSteps: Use encyclopedias (e.g., Canadian Encyclopedic Digest) for overviews.
Consult textbooks for doctrinal clarity.
Check law review articles for deeper analysis.

topics.title: Researching Limitation Periods
topics.coreDefinition: Limitation periods restrict the time within which a legal action may be commenced. They vary by jurisdiction and cause of action.
frameworkSteps: Identify jurisdiction.
Locate the relevant Limitations Act.
Determine discovery date and applicable exceptions.
Confirm tolling or extension rules.
quickExamples: Ontario’s basic two-year limitation period (subject to exceptions).
commonMistakes: Confusing event date with discovery date.

intentSignals: am i too late to sue

notes: This pack supports structured responses when users ask how to research or verify legal information.
Always require jurisdiction when discussing procedure or limitation periods.
Encourage consulting official sources and legal professionals for confirmation.
